dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, the coronavirus outbreak in China has led to some major business shutdowns—Burger King and Universal Studios were among the first to close up shop there last week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, the coronavirus outbreak in China has led to some major business shutdowns-Burger King and Universal Studios were among the first to close up shop there last week.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: McDonalds and Disney were among the first companies to shutter businesses in China last week: Disney has shut down its Shanghai and Hong Kong theme parks, while McDonalds said that it had suspended business across five cities in the Hubei Province (the center of the outbreak).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's not just theme parks—Starbucks closed more than half of its 4,100 stores in mainland China. That's a huge operational hit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's not just theme parks-Starbucks closed more than half of its four thousand, one hundred stores in mainland China. That's a huge operational hit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Starbucks quickly followed suitit has now closed more than half of its 4,100 stores in mainland China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and retailers like H&M shut down 45 locations. They're also suspending employee travel to and from China, according to Reuters.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and retailers like H&M shut down forty five locations. They're also suspending employee travel to and from China, according to Reuters.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Big retailers have also shut down stores with H&M closing 45 locations and suspending business travel to and from China for its employees, according to Reuters.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: I mean, that makes sense, but it's still staggering how widespread this is. Even IKEA and Uniqlo closed stores in Wuhan and Hubei.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I mean, that makes sense, but it's still staggering how widespread this is. Even IKEA and Uniqlo closed stores in Wuhan and Hubei.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Other companies such as IKEA and Swatch have closed stores in Wuhan, while Japanese conglomerate Fast Retailing shuttered nearly 100 of its Uniqlo stores in the Hubei province.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And hotels aren't immune either. Marriott, Hyatt, Hilton—all scaling back operations in the region.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And hotels aren't immune either. Marriott, Hyatt, Hilton-all scaling back operations in the region.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Several hotels including Marriott, Hyatt and Hilton have also suspended some operations within Wuhan and the greater Hubei province.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Cruise lines too! Carnival and Royal Caribbean canceled voyages. MGM even scaled back Lunar New Year celebrations in Macao.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Cruise lines too! Carnival and Royal Caribbean canceled voyages. M G M even scaled back Lunar New Year celebrations in Macao.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tour operators Carnival and Royal Carribean Cruises canceled several scheduled voyages, while casino operator MGM Resorts said its scaled back its Lunar New Year celebration at its Macao resort last weekend.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Travel restrictions are really piling up. Facebook and Microsoft asked employees to avoid non-essential travel to China.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Travel restrictions are really piling up. Facebook and Microsoft asked employees to avoid non-essential travel to China.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tech giants like Facebook and Microsoft, for example, recently asked all of its employees to suspend non-essential travel to mainland China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Big banks like Standard Chartered and Commonwealth Bank of Australia are doing the same. Samsung and LG Electronics too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Big banks like Standard Chartered and Commonwealth Bank of Australia are doing the same. Samsung and L G Electronics too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Big banks, like Standard Chartered and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, also said employee trips to China should be avoided. Other companies banning travel to and from China include Japans Nippon Steel and South Koreas LG Electronics.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Automakers like Fiat Chrysler restricted travel to Wuhan, though GM and Ford are holding off on broader China bans for now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Automakers like Fiat Chrysler restricted travel to Wuhan, though G M and Ford are holding off on broader China bans for now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Large automakers, such as Fiat Chrysler, have also restricted travel to Wuhan as well as other Chinese cities. General Motors and Ford, while restricting business trips to Wuhan, have yet to suspend travel to other parts of China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild—the Chinese government locked down over a dozen cities, affecting like 50 million people's travel plans.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild-the Chinese government locked down over a dozen cities, affecting like fifty million people's travel plans.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Chinese government has locked down more than a dozen cities in an attempt to quarantine the coronavirus resulting in restricted travel for some 50 million people and complicated it for many others.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And now airlines, hotels, booking sites are offering free cancellations for China trips. Just a massive ripple effect.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And now airlines, hotels, booking sites are offering free cancellations for China trips. Just a massive ripple effect.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A host of airlines, hotels, booking platforms and travel agencies are offering free cancellations and date changes for those who had earlier purchased trips to China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, it's one of those situations where you see how interconnected global business really is, for better or worse.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, it's one of those situations where you see how interconnected global business really is, for better or worse.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Let's hope containment efforts ramp up quickly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Let's hope containment efforts ramp up quickly.

artist_script:
HostA: Okay, so, the coronavirus outbreak in China has led to some major business shutdowns—Burger King and Universal Studios were among the first to close up shop there last week.
HostB: Yeah, and it’s not just theme parks—Starbucks closed more than half of its 4,100 stores in mainland China. That’s a huge operational hit.
HostA: Right, and retailers like H&M shut down 45 locations. They’re also suspending employee travel to and from China, according to Reuters.
HostB: I mean, that makes sense, but it’s still staggering how widespread this is. Even IKEA and Uniqlo closed stores in Wuhan and Hubei.
HostA: And hotels aren’t immune either. Marriott, Hyatt, Hilton—all scaling back operations in the region.
HostB: Cruise lines too! Carnival and Royal Caribbean canceled voyages. MGM even scaled back Lunar New Year celebrations in Macao.
HostA: Travel restrictions are really piling up. Facebook and Microsoft asked employees to avoid non-essential travel to China.
HostB: Big banks like Standard Chartered and Commonwealth Bank of Australia are doing the same. Samsung and LG Electronics too.
HostA: Automakers like Fiat Chrysler restricted travel to Wuhan, though GM and Ford are holding off on broader China bans for now.
HostB: It’s wild—the Chinese government locked down over a dozen cities, affecting like 50 million people’s travel plans.
HostA: And now airlines, hotels, booking sites are offering free cancellations for China trips. Just a massive ripple effect.
HostB: Honestly, it’s one of those situations where you see how interconnected global business really is, for better or worse.
HostA: Absolutely. Let’s hope containment efforts ramp up quickly.
